msDesc.head: Composite anthology of Middle English verse and prose in two parts, partially the work of John Shirley

physDesc.p: Composite in two parts: A || B

extent.seg: x (modern end leaves, paper) + ii (fifteenth-century bifolium, parchment, containing table of contents, unfoliated) + 1-134 (fifteenth-century, paper) + 135-184 (sixteenth-century, paper) + ix (modern end leaves, paper)

binding.p: Late seventeenth-century calf binding over pasteboards, with raised sewing supports and gold-tooled laurel wreath design on spine, typical of Elias Ashmole's collection.

history.provenance: The manuscript consists of three codicological units which were produced separately and later joined, and which appear to be unrelated to each other. Provenance for each part has been recorded separately, and the provenance of the composite manuscript in its current state is recorded here.

The two composite parts were likely compiled together by Elias Ashmole, who bequeathed the complete manuscript to the Ashmolean Museum in 1692, in one volume, as part of his donation of 1,100 printed books and 600 manuscripts. The first composite part was likely acquired from the poet William Brown(e) (1590-c. 1640) after his death, from whom Ashmole also acquired other manuscripts (now MS Ashmole 40 and MS Ashmole 767). It is uncertain how or where Ashmole procured the second composite part.
history.acquisition: The manuscript was kept in the Ashmolean until 1860, when the collection was transferred to the Bodleian Library.

recordHist.source: Description by Charlotte Ross (April 2023), with consultation of the original. Previous summary description based on Watson, the Quarto Catalogue (W. H. Black, A descriptive, analytical, and critical catalogue of the manuscripts bequeathed unto the University of Oxford by Elias Ashmole Esq...., Quarto Catalogues X, 1845) and supplementary sources. Quarto Catalogue, cols. 95–6 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 97–8 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 99–100 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 101–2 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 103–4 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 1123

listBibl.bibl: A. G. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts c.435–1600 in Oxford Libraries (Oxford, 1984), no. 32 [fols. 1–133]
Secretum secretorum: Nine English Versions, ed. M A Manzalaoui, Early English Text Society o.s. 276 (Oxford, 1977)
R. J. Lyall, Materials: The Paper Revolution, Book Production and Publishing in Britain 1395-1475, eds J. Griffiths and D. Pearsall (Cambridge, 1989)
Eleanor Prescott Hammond, Lydgate and the Duchess of Gloucester, Anglia 27 (1904): 381-98.

msItem.note: blank

John Shirley's decorative ownership inscription ma ioye A Shirley, with a crown insignia above the A. Similar ownership inscriptions appear in Cambridge University Library, MS Ff.1.33 and British Library, Royal MS 20 B XV.

msItem.title: Latin verse
msItem.incipit: Non homo mireris si copia tu fluat eris
msItem.note: A later hand, possibly William Brown(e), corrects mireris to leteris. The first four lines of this verse also appear on folio 43r, along with another two lines not present here. They are also witnessed in British Library MS Additional 16165 (fol. iiiv).

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.note: This list of texts does not correspond to the contents of the manuscript. As it is written in John Shirley's hand, it was likely taken from another of Shirley's poetic anthologies and added to this manuscript in error. This confusion was likely due to the coincidence of the first and last items in the table of contents being the same as the manuscript.
A mid sixteenth-century hand notes the contents of the manuscript: Certē peeces of Lydgates, Chaucers, and Gowres workes, but ye moste are Lydgates.

physDesc.additions:
Folio 1v, containing Shirley's ownership inscription, also contains three merchant’s marks in two styles which are not original but likely of the late fifteenth or early sixteenth century. The uppermost mark is smudged and difficult to identify, in a rough reverse 4 shape with a loop to the left and a flourished descender. The lower two marks are better preserved: a reverse 4 shape with a cross to the left and an initial h or b formed from the descender with flourishes. Both marks unidentified, although the style of combining a 4 with a letter is also seen in personal seal designs in late medieval England.
Erased writing visible under UV on folio i v, some with hints of rubrication. Folio ii v contains a fragment of faint writing in a later hand at the foot of the page and inverted.

history.provenance: Analysis under UV light suggests the parchment of this bifolium may be recycled and once contained text which has now been erased.

The flyleaves contain the ownership mark and hand of John Shirley, but were likely taken from another of his manuscripts as the contents do not match those contained in the first codicological unit. The practice of surrounding a paper text block with parchment end leaves was Shirley's preferred method of construction (see British Library Additional MS 16165). No manuscripts survive which contain this collection of texts. It is unclear when this bifolium was attached to the manuscript, but it was likely before 1614.

A late fifteenth-century inscription at the top of folio ii r, now partly erased, reads Iste liber datur in vadium dno David G 1486. This ownership cannot be ascribed to the rest of the manuscript with any certainty, as the flyleaves were taken from another manuscript which may have belonged to this name.
The hand of the poet William Brown(e) (1590-c. 1645) is seen in annotations on folio ii v; he also records his name on folio 1r: Liber W. Browne; and folio 133v: W. Browne Inter. Templi, 1614.

msPart.head: Anthology of Middle English prose and verse, predominantly by Lydgate but also containing Chaucer, Gower, and Scogan. In the hand of John Shirley

msItem.author: Ps.-Aristotle
msItem.title: Secreta secretorum
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþe [þe] boke made of þe governance of Princes compyled by þat renommed Phylosophre Daune Aristotiles and sent to þat excellent Emperour and Prince
msItem.incipit: MArmaduke þe sone of patryke þe sage of alle langages
msItem.explicit: to abstene þee frome to miche eting and superfluite is þe souerine medecyne generally
msItem.finalRubric:
Et sic explicit Decretum Aristotelis
And begynneþe þabstracte Brevyaire compyled of diuers balades &c
msItem.note:
Middle English 'Marmaduke' prose translation. Edited in Secretum secretorum: Nine English Versions, ed. M A Manzalaoui, Early English Text Society o.s. 276 (Oxford, 1977), 203-224.
IMEP IX.

msItemStruct.note: The following texts in the first part of the manuscript are marked with the rubric: Here begynneþe boke cleped þe Abstracte Brevyayre compyled of divers balades, roundels, virilayes, tragedyes, envoyes, compleyntes, moralites, storyes, practysed and eke devysed and ymagyned, as it sheweþe here folowyng

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fall of Princes
msItem.rubric: þe Tragedye of Rome by Lidegate
msItem.incipit:
ROme Remembre of þy fundacoun
And of what people þou toke þy gynnyng
msItem.explicit:
Let þestates of þere burthe honurable
Voyde al raskayle and wedde þere semblable
msItem.note:
Three extracts from Lydgate's Fall of Princes: II.4460-4592 (fols. 13r-15r), III.1569-1638 (fols. 15r-16v), II.2584-2639 (fols. 16v-17v). The second extract on folio 15r opens with the rubric Lenvoye by Lidegate, erroneously positioned one stanza early. The third extract on folio 16v opens with the rubric þis moral Epistel sent kynge Amasias to kynge Johas made by Dann Johan Lidegate þe poete of Bury.
IMEV 1168.

msItem.author: John Gower
msItem.title: Balade moral of gode counseyle
msItem.rubric: Balade moral of gode counseyle made by Gower
msItem.incipit:
PAsse forþe þou pilgryme and bridel wele þy beeste
Loke not ageine for thing þat may betyde
msItem.explicit:
Remembre eke þat what men doþe amisse
þou haste or arte or may be suche as he is
msItem.note:
Eight seven-line stanzas. Edited in English Works of John Gower, ed. George Campbell Macaulay, Early English Text Society e.s. 81, 82 (Oxford, 1900, 1901, repr. 1978), clxxiii.
IMEV 2737.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: How every thing draweþe to his semblable
msItem.rubric: Here nowe foloweþe a balade ryal made by Lydegate affter his resorte to his religyoun with þe refrayde howe every thing draweþe to his semblable
msItem.incipit:
TRete every man as he is disposed
With holy men entrete of holinesse
msItem.explicit:
Prerogatyff moste souereine of honour
Un to his ymage list make þe semblable
msItem.note:
Imperfect, twenty four eight-line stanzas of twenty five, missing stanza 12. The final line and explicit are written in the margin, in the same hand. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. Henry Noble MacCracken, Early English Text Society o.s. 192 (Oxford, 1934, repr. 1961), 801-8.
IMEV 3800.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Prayer to our Lady
msItem.incipit:
OR dliectus meus shewde dileccoun
desired me vnder his vmbracoun
msItem.explicit:
O filia Syon laudabilis nimis
Iam sonet vox tua in auribus
msItem.note:
Nine eight-line stanzas. Edited in A.S.G. Edwards and A.W. Jenkins, A Hymn to the Virgin: By Lydgate?, Medieval Studies 35 (1973): 60-6.
IMEV 2816.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Prayer to St. Edmund
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe a balade ryal of Invocacoun to saint Edmunde at þinstance of kynge Henry þe sixst made by Lidgate
msItem.incipit:
GLorious martir þat of devoute humblesse
ffor Crystes sake was bounden til a tree
msItem.explicit:
Beoþe to his chirche defence and champioun
By cause it is of youre foundacyoun
msItem.note:
Eight eight-line stanzas. Unedited.
IMEV 2445. Includes an envoy comprising six eight-line stanzas (also unedited, IMEV 928. Titled in the scribe's hand Envoy to Henry VI, Life of St Edmund and begins on folio 23v Go lytel booke be ferful qwake for drede
ffor to appere in any so heghe presence.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Isopes Fabules
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþe a notable proverbe of ysopus Ethiopyene in balad by dann Johan Lidegate made in Oxenford
msItem.incipit:
AN olde proverbe haþe bee seyde and shal
Touchyng þe void of gredye coveytyse
msItem.explicit:
Lyche þe grehounde nought content wit one cheese
Desireþe tweyne þer fore he dye boþe leese
msItem.note:
Imperfect, containing only four stanzas of fable VII. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 566.
IMEV 4178.

msItem.author: Henry Scogan
msItem.title: Moral Ballade
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe nexst a moral balade to my lord þe Prince to my lord of Clarence to my lord of Bedford and to my lorde of Gloucestre by Henry Scogan at a souper of feorþe merchande in þe vyntre in londone at þe hous of Lowys Johan
msItem.incipit:
MY noble sonnes and eke my lordes dere
I youre fader called vnworþely
msItem.explicit:
God you conferme in vertuous goodnesse
So þat thorughe necgligence yee no thing leese
msItem.note:
Twenty one eight-line stanzas. Three stanzas of another text interpolated between stanzas 13 and 14, without break but with marginal note - see next item.
IMEV 2264.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Gentillesse
msItem.rubric: Geffrey Chaucier made þeos thre balades nexst þat folowen
msItem.incipit:
þe first fader and foundour of gentylesse
What man þat claymeþe gentyle for to be
msItem.explicit:
þat maþe his heyre him þat wol him qweme
Al were he mytre crowne or dyademe
msItem.note:
Three eight-line stanzas. Interpolated into Henry Scogan's poem Moral Ballade. Edited in A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems, in 3 vols., ed. Frederick James Furnivall, Chaucer Society 1st Series 21, 57, 58 (London, repr. 1967).
IMEV 3348.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fall of Princes
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe a balade by a gode Clerk made þat is cleped presbiter Johannes to advertyse þe hye prynces þat haue þe power of þe pepul to governe hem & counsel and vertue
msItem.incipit:
ÞEre is no damage more man to purpose
Ne for to be drede is more lamentable
msItem.explicit:
ffor some tunges touchen ay tresoun
And gif no credence witoute auisement
msItem.note:
Imperfect extracts from Lydgate's Fall of Princes: II. 4593-4606, 4614-4627 (with the transposition of 4623-4624 and 4625-4627), 4624-4662, 4558-4560, 4820-4844 (with the transposition of 4840-4841 and 4842-4843).
IMEV 1168.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Consulo quisque eris
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe a poetycal balade of wysdame made by þe Munke of Bury cleped Johan Lidegate
msItem.incipit:
COvnseyllier where þat ever þou be
Of plolicye for sight and prudence
msItem.explicit:
Twene vyce and vertue to sette a difference
To his plesaunce so grante oure pilgrimage
msItem.note:
Fifteen eight-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961),750-4.
IMEV 1294.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Midsomer Rose
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe a balade made of þe transmutacouns of þis worlde wit þe refrayde as a midsomer Roos
msItem.incipit:
LEt noman booste of konnyng ne vertue
Of tresore ricchesse or of sapience
msItem.explicit:
Called þe Ryver with þe red streme
To paradyse wardes un to Ihesu oure Roos
msItem.note:
Imperfect: fourteen eight-line stanzas of fifteen, missing stanza 8. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 780-5.
IMEV 1865.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A dyte of womenhis hornys
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe nowe a moral balade withe Refrayde if hornes were awaye bytwene nature and bewte &c by Lidegate
msItem.incipit:
Off god and kynde procedeþe al beautee
Yitte crafft cane shewe aforeine apparence
msItem.explicit:
Noble Pryncesse of meeke benyvolence
Ben saumple your hornes caste a way
msItem.note:
Imperfect: seven eight-line stanzas of ten, missing stanzas 5 and 8. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 662-5.
IMEV 2625.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: To fynde a freond at neode
msItem.rubric: þan foloweþe nowe a notable moralisacoun made by Lidegate of a fabul poetical . howe trees chose hem a kyng bytwene þe þe Ryal Cydre of þe hye mountayne and þe thowthistelle of þe lowe valeye . þis moralisacioun is in þis same boke to fore . And wryt a poletyke balade wit refrayde, to finde a frende at nede
msItem.incipit:
Vhane Aurora toke of Tytan hir leve
Nought yoore agone in a gladde mornyng
msItem.explicit:
Gret coustume is a bowte þe tree
While þat þe bowes beene wit frutyes lade
msItem.note:
Imperfect: the first twelve lines of seventeen stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 755-9.
IMEV 3034.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: To fynde a freond at neode
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþe a Polletyke Balade ryale made by þat approbate Poete Lidegate þe Munk of Burye wit with þe gode Refrayde, To fynde a freonde at neode
msItem.incipit:
Late whane Aurora of Tytane toke leve
Nought longe agone in a gladde mornyng
msItem.explicit:
ffor Maries sake be oure proteccoun
And helpe alle þoo þat calne þee at þeire nede
msItem.note:
The perfect version of the previous text, in seventeen eight-line stanzas, with a variant copy of the first twelve lines. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 755-9.
IMEV 3034.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Balade of Fortune
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe nowe a compleynte of þe pleintyff ageinst ageinst fortune translated oute of ffrenshe in to Englisshe by þat famous Rethorissyene Geffrey Chaucier
msItem.incipit:
This wrecched worldes transmutacoun
As wele and woo nowe poure and nowe honour
msItem.explicit:
ffor to folowe by wordes þe curyoustee
Of hem þat vsen for to make in ffraunce
msItem.note:
Imperfect: the Envoy from Chaucer's Complaint of Venus is erroneously added to the end of the text (also witnessed in British Library, Harley MS 2251), to form nine eight-line stanzas plus two envoy stanzas. Each envoy stanza is titled in the margin Lenvoye de ffortune and Lenvoye by Chaucyer. Edited in A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems, in 3 vols., ed. Frederick James Furnivall, Chaucer Society 1st Series 21, 57, 58 (London, repr. 1967).
IMEV 3661 and 3542.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Chaucer's Chronicle
msItem.rubric: Here nowe folowe þe names of þe nyene worshipfullest Ladyes þat in alle cronycles and storyal bokes haue ben foundene of trouþe of constaunce and vertuous or reproched womenhode by Chaucier
msItem.incipit:
GRete Rayson Cleopatre is þy Kyndnesse
Be putte in mynde and also þyne hyenesse
msItem.explicit:
Where þat of yowe þe goddes hade grete pitee
And lyche seemewes transfourmed him and þee
msItem.note:
The sole witness of this text, in nine eight-line stanzas. Edited in Odd Texts of the Minor Poems, in 2 vols., ed. Frederick James Furnivall, Chaucer Society 1st Series 23, 60 (London, 1868, 1880, repr. 1967), App. v-viii.
IMEV 1016.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Balade in Commendation of Our Lady
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe nexst a devoute balade by Lidegate of Bury made at þe reverence of oure lady Qwene of mercy
msItem.incipit:
A Thowsande stories I kouþe to you reherce
Of olde clerkis touching þe matere
msItem.explicit:
Vn knowing him bare Tryste by gret myracle
And of Ihesus manhode truwe tabernacle
msItem.note:
Eveven seven-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 254-60.
IMEV 99.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Amor et Pecunia
msItem.rubric: Nowe foloweþe here nexst a questyoun made in wyse of balade by þat Philosofre Lidegate daun Johan . Wheþer is moste prefered in þe worlde þat nowe is, Amor vincit omnia . or Mentiris quod pecunia
msItem.incipit:
EChe man to folowe his owen fantasye
Lyche as it falleþe in fallþe in his opynioun
msItem.explicit:
Suche love graunted in trouþe and stabulnesse
Shal haue his guerdoun and his mede
msItem.note:
Seventeen eight-line stanzas. Six lines of Latin verse have been added to the end of the text, with the rubric Versus philosophorum, as a continuation of the same text. The first four lines agree with those on the flyleaf i v. The Middle English is edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 744-9.
IMEV 698.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: The Complaint of Venus
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþe a balade made by þat worþy knight of Savoye in frensche calde sir Otes Graunson translated by Chauciers
msItem.incipit:
There nys so hye comfort to my plesaunce
Whane þat I am in any hevynesse
msItem.explicit:
To folowe worde by worde þe curyoustee
Of Granson flour of hem þat make in ffraunce
msItem.note:
Complete text, with the same envoy from item 17 Balade of Fortune added to the end. Eight eight-line stanzas plus envoy. Edited in A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems, in 3 vols., ed. Frederick James Furnivall, Chaucer Society 1st Series 21, 57, 58 (London, repr. 1967).
IMEV 3542.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Invocation to St. Anne
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþe a devoute Invocacoun to sainte Anne by þat solempne Religious Lidegate made at þe commaundement of my ladye Anne Countasse of Stafford
msItem.incipit:
THowe first mouver þar causest al thynge
To haue his keping thorughe þy provydence
msItem.explicit:
He graunte vs mercy in his exyle here
Sith he vs bought wit his blode so dere
msItem.note:
Eleven seven-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 130-3.
IMEV 3671.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A Lover’s Lament
msItem.rubric: Here folowþe nexst a compleynte made by Lydegate for þe departing of Thomas Chaucier in to ffraunce by hes servauntz vpon þe kynges ambassate
msItem.incipit:
Every maner creature
disposed vn to gentylesse
msItem.explicit:
þat of mercy shee not disdeyne
To bee my souerine ladye dere
msItem.note:
Fifteen eight-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 420-4.
IMEV 746.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Beware of Doublenesse
msItem.rubric: Nowe here foloweþe a balade made by Lidegate of wymenne ffor desporte and game per Antyfrasim
msItem.incipit:
The worlde is nowe full of al variaunce
In every thing who þat taþe gode hede
msItem.explicit:
Sette on youre brest youre selff & assure
A mighty sheelde of doubulnesse
msItem.note:
Imperfect: eleven eight-line stanzas of thirteen, stanzas 8 and 10 missing. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 438-42.
IMEV 3656.

msItem.title: A Holy Meditation
msItem.rubric: Here nowe foloweþe an holy meditacioun made by þe Religious man Lidegate daun Johan þe Munk of Bury
msItem.incipit:
Affter þe stormy tyme cessinge þe rayne
Whane for þabsence of colde þeorþe is fayne
msItem.explicit:
If þowe do þus þane shal þy soule weende
To hevens blisse which þat haþenone ende
msItem.note:
Ninety couplets. Once thought to have been written by Chaucer - for this debate, see Germaine Dempster, Chaucer’s ‘Wretched Engendering’ and ‘An Holy Medytacion, Modern Philology 35:1 (1937): 27-9. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 43-8.
IMEV 131.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Valentine to Our Lady
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe nowe a glorious Invocacoun to oure blessed ladye made by þat vertuous Lidegate in balade wyse in cheosing of Valantynes at þat selff feeste with þe Refrayde I love one best of alle
msItem.incipit:
SAinte Valentyne of custume yeere by yeere
Men haue in vsaunce with þis Regyoun
msItem.explicit:
Have on vs mercy whane we for helpe calle
ffor love of hir þat þus excelliþe alle
msItem.note:
Twenty seven-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 304-10.
IMEV 3065.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: To King Henry VI on his Coronation
msItem.rubric: Nowe here foloweþe nexst a balade made by þat solempne clerk Lidegate daun Johan . presented to kynge henry þe sixst his soverine Lorde. þe daye of þat royal solempnysacoun of his coronacoun at Westminster
msItem.incipit:
MOost noble Prynce of cristen Prynces alle
fflouring in yowþe and vertuous Innosence
msItem.explicit:
And god shal sende þee frome þe heven dovne
Grace and gode hure to þy roial estate
msItem.finalRubric: Lenvoy to þe kinge henry þe sixst by Lidegate
msItem.note:
Eighteen eight-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 324-30.
IMEV 2211.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: On Kissing at Verbum caro factum est
msItem.rubric: A folowing begynneþe þis balade nest folowing of þe Lenvoye of þe same to þe Qweene . And þane shoule yee rede nexst a devoute seyinge of verbum caro factum est
msItem.incipit:
YEe devoute peple wheoche haue observaunce
Mekely in churches to kysse stoone or tree
msItem.explicit:
And ay haue mynde of Crystes passyoun
Whiche for þy sake werde þe crowne of thorne
msItem.finalRubric: Nowe endeþe here þe dyte of verbum caro factum est
msItem.note:
Four eight-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 116-7.
IMEV 4245.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A Complaint for my Lady of Gloucester and Holland
msItem.rubric: and nexst foloweþe a Pytous complaynte of a Chapellayne of my lordes of Gloucester Humfrey &c whome gode assoyle þat noble Prynce
msItem.incipit:
A Solytarye ful sore compleyninge
Hevy sate weeping on a Ryver syde
msItem.explicit:
þat clere troyth may þanne shewe his face
Boþe wychche and bawde far aweye to chace
msItem.note:
Imperfect, lines 1-110 only due to the loss of a leaf. Fifteen seven-line stanzas and one five-line stanza with the beginning of the next line as a catchword,. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 608-13.
IMEV 92.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fall of Princes
msItem.rubric: Tragedye made by Lidegate
msItem.incipit:
His kyngdame eke brought to destrucoun
Loo here þe fyne of prynces vicyous
msItem.explicit:
Lych Syrynes with voyces malodyous
Blannndisshe youre eris to make you lechcherous
msItem.note:
Extract from Lydgate's Fall of Princes: 31 lines, III.1608-1639.
IMEV 1168.

msItem.title: Garter list
msItem.rubric: Here folowen þe names of þe ordre of knightes of þe Garter
msItem.note: IMEP IX.

msItem.author: John Shirley
msItem.title: Shirley's Bookplate
msItem.incipit:
Yee þat desyre in herte and have plesaunce
Olde stories in bokis for to rede
msItem.explicit:
Whane yee þis boke haue over redde and seyne
To Johan Shirley restore yee it ageine
msItem.note:
John Shirley's bookplate in seven lines, a variant of which also appears in Cambridge, Trinity College R.3.20.
IMEV 4260.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: An Epistell to Sibille
msItem.rubric:
Lenvoye by Lidegate
Here foloweþe an Epistel made by þe same Lidegate sende to Sibille with þeschewing of ydelnesse
msItem.incipit:
The chief gynnyng of grace and of vertue
To exclude slouþe is ocupacoun
msItem.explicit:
Let hie labour avoyding ydelnesse
Vsinge hir handes in vertuous besynesse
msItem.note:
The sole witness. Twenty one seven-line stanzas - stanza 18 is repeated. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 14-18.
IMEV 3321.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Mumming at Bishopswood
msItem.rubric: Nowe here nexst folowyng ys made a balade by Lydegate sente by a pour syant to þe Shirreves of Londone acompanyed with þeire breþerne vponne Mayes daye at Busshopes wode at an honurable dyner eche of hem bringginge his dysshe
msItem.incipit:
MIghty fflourra goddes of fresshe floures
Whiche cloþed hast þe soyle in lousty grene
msItem.explicit:
And al þat may youre hyenesse qweeme and pleese
In any parte or doone youre hertes eese
msItem.note:
Sixteen seven-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 668-71.
IMEV 2170.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Stabat mater dolorosa
msItem.rubric: Here nowe filoweþe nexst a devoute Invocacoun to oure Ladye with þe þe refrayde Stabat mater dolorosa
msItem.incipit:
HEyle goddes moder dolorous
By þe crosse stonding forwepped
msItem.explicit:
þowe helpe me in þat stronge stour
Whane þey frome hens wolde me take
msItem.note:
The sole witness. Twenty three couplets. Edited in Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century, ed. Carleton Fairchild Brown (Oxford: Clarendon, 1939), 22-5.
IMEV 1048.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A devowte invocacioun to Sainte Denys
msItem.rubric: And nowe foloweþe here a dovowte Invocacoun made by Lydegate to sainte Denys at þe request of Charlles þe Frenshe Kynge to let it bee translated oute of Frenshe in to Englisshe
msItem.incipit:
O þow chosen of gode protectour of ffraunce
þow richchest rubye of þeire felicitee
msItem.explicit:
To fore þe heghe devyne magestee
And preye þe lord taccepte oure preyer
msItem.note:
The sole witness. Nine eight-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 127-9.
IMEV 2566.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A lament of the Virgin Mary
msItem.rubric:
Here nowe foloweþe a pytous lamentacoun of oure ladye shewde to saint Auncyoun of Cristes passyoun made by John
Lidegate
msItem.incipit:
IN þe tourret of a toure I stode musinge on þe moone
A comly qweene of honour Appered in goostly sighte soone
msItem.explicit:
ffor þee mankynde þe trouth to telle Bethenke þee wele telle on have doo
Aske þowe me helpe and I shal doo and save þee Quia amore langveo
msItem.note:
Eleven eight-line stanzas with refrain. Edited in Religious Lyrics of the XIV Century, ed. Brown (1924), 234-7.
IMEV 1460.

msItem.author: Saint Augustine, Bishop of Hippo
msItem.title: on the Virtues of the Mass
msItem.rubric: Here nexst foloweþe þe wrytinge of þe doctoure saint Austyne what mede man resceyveþe þat devoutely hereþe his messe
msItem.incipit:
NOwe vnderstonde beþe more and lesse
What mede yee resceyve to here youre messe
msItem.explicit:
þis grace and pardone for to have
þeire bodye and soule for to save
msItem.note:
The sole witness. Seventeen couplets. Edited in Peter J. Lucas, The Versions by John Shirley, William Gybbe and Another of the Poem On the Virtues of the Mass: A Collation, Notes and Queries n.s. 28 (1981): 394-8.
IMEV 2373.

msItem.title: Against Swearing
msItem.rubric: And nowe folowen þe wordes of monisshone of oure lord ihesu crist saide to saint Jerome and to saint Gregorie
msItem.incipit: Who so ever he beo þat useþe to swere by þe holy membres of oure lorde ihesu Criste
msItem.explicit: god sende yowe grace of Amendement and beware in penaunce of god
msItem.note: Prose. IMEP IX.

msItem.title: A hymn on the Five Joys
msItem.rubric: Nowe foloweþe here nexst a devoute and holy salutacoun of oure ladye made by an holy Ankaresse of Maunsffeld
msItem.incipit:
HEille glorious virgyne grounde of al oure grace
Heyle mayde and moder in virgynitee
msItem.explicit:
Heyle sawe to seeke vs synners sende socour
þees ioyes fyve surmountinge in oure mynde
msItem.note:
Five eight-line stanzas. Shirley attributes the text to an anchoress of Maunsfeld. The text has been attributed to Lidgate by Stow in BL Add.29729. Edited in Religious Lyrics of the XIV Century, ed. Brown (1924), 53-4.
IMEV 1406.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: On the Image of Pity
msItem.rubric: Here foloweþe a devoute exortacoun to meeve menne devoutely to þe ymage of pyte by orisounes and preyers
msItem.incipit:
O wrechched synner what so ever þowe be
With hert indurate herder þane þe stoone
msItem.explicit:
þat holsome stories shewed in figure
May rest with vs in moste duwe remembrance
msItem.note:
Imperfect: four eight-line stanzas of five. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 297-9.
IMEV 2588.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Deus in Nomine Tuo saluum me Fac
msItem.rubric: Nowe foloweþe þe salme of deus in nomine tuo translated owte of latyne in to englisshe by Lydegate daun Johan
msItem.incipit:
GOd in þy name make me sauf and sovnde
And in þy vertue me deme and iustefye
msItem.explicit:
With oyle of mercye to meschef medcynable
þowe heele myne hert whyle I haue lyves space
msItem.note:
Imperfect: eight eight-line stanzas of nine. Missing stanza added on folio 134v. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. I: Religious Poems, ed. MacCracken (1911, repr. 1961), 10-12.
IMEV 951.

msItem.title: Seven Wise Counsels
msItem.rubric: Here nowe foloweþe þe doctryne of many gret Clerkes approved made in baladewyse and translated oute of divers langages in to englisshe
msItem.incipit:
By sapience tempre þy courage
Of hasty yre daunte þy passiouns
msItem.explicit:
With hole herte body wille and mynde
To be contente with suche as þey fynde
msItem.note:
Nine seven-line stanzas. Edited in Max Förster, Kleine Mitteilungen zur mittelenglische Lehrdichtung, VI., Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und Literaturen 104 (1900): 293-309.
IMEV 576.

msItem.title: Of the Four Complexions
msItem.rubric: Here nexst foloweþe þe foure complexcyons of man kynde with þe doomis of hem made by discrete Clerkes
msItem.incipit:
Off gifftes large to love haþe gret delite
Ioyous and gladde aye of laughing chere
msItem.explicit:
Coward of kynde whane he shoulde be a man
þowe shalt him knowe by visage pale and wane
msItem.note:
Imperfect: three seven-line stanzas, missing the stanza on Fleumaticus. Each stanza is followed by Latin hexameter couplet. Edited in Henry Axel Person, Cambridge Middle English Lyrics (Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1953; rev. ed. 1962), 50-2.
IMEV 2624.

msItem.author: John Lydgate (attributed)
msItem.title: Four things that make a man fall from Reason
msItem.rubric: þe philosofar writeþe for a souereine notabilite þat foure thinges makeþe þe prudence of man to falle
msItem.incipit:
Worship wymen and vnweldy age
Make men fonde for lak in þere resoun
msItem.explicit:
And bookis þat poetes wrot and radde
Seyne wymen mooste make men to madde
msItem.note:
One seven-line stanza, attributed to Lydgate. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 709.
IMEV 4230.

msItem.title: Prophecy of Merlin
msItem.rubric: Profecia merlini
msItem.incipit:
Gens erit australis rector regni generalis
Et regit injuste, periet quoque postea juste
msItem.note: Two-lines, unedited.

msItem.title: Þe seynge of wyse men
msItem.incipit:
Þat man is wys and weele fortunate
Þat by oþer men can leorne to eschieve
msItem.explicit:
He may be cleped felix men may defiyse
Þus may harme be cleped profitable
msItem.note:
The sole witness. One seven-line stanza and one six-line stanza. Unedited.
IMEV 3286.

msItem.title: Six Biblical questions and answers
msItem.incipit: Who was ded ande never borne , Adam þat was oure first beforne
msItem.explicit: Who spake or þat he was borne , John baptiste of olde in þe moder wombe
msItem.note:
The sole witness. Six couplets. A seventh is added in a later hand. Edited by Max Förster, Kleinere mittelenglische texte, Anglia 42 (1918): 145-224.
IMEV 4111.

msItem.title: Þe Ten Commandments
msItem.incipit:
þowe shalt haue one god and no moo
þou shalt not swere in veyne al so
msItem.explicit:
þy neghboires wyf coveyte þou nought
hors oxse asse no oþer ought
msItem.note:
Imperfect: five of twelve couplets. Edited by Speculum Christiani, ed. Gustaf Holmstedt, Early English Text Society o.s. 182 (1933, repr. 1988), lxxiv-lxxv.
IMEV 3685.

msItem.title: Devoute & vertuos wordes
msItem.incipit:
þere is none so wyse man but he may wisdame Leere
þere is none so stronge man but he may fynde his peere
msItem.explicit:
þere is none so fals man but some man may him leve
þere is none so meke a man but some man may him greve
msItem.note:
Four long lines. Edited by Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century, ed. Brown (1939), 285.
IMEV 3538.

msItem.title: Thou that weared the crown of thorns
msItem.incipit:
þou þat werred þe crowne of thornes
ffell dovne þe pryde of wommens hornes
msItem.explicit:
Lord for þy peyneful passyoun
To save oure soule frome dampnacoun
msItem.note:
The sole witness. Eight lines with couplet. Edited by Historical Poems of the XIV and XV Centuries, ed. Rossell Hope Robbins (New York: Columbia UP, 1959), 139.
IMEV 3698.

msItem.title: And ever the higher that thow art
msItem.incipit:
And ever þe hyer þat þowe erte
So muche lower bee þyne herte
msItem.note:
The sole witness. One couplet. Unedited.
IMEV 299.5.

msItem.title: Poem on good counsel
msItem.incipit:
Love gentyl Ihesu fervently Adversete take pacyently
Prosperyty vse it mekely Heven to reioyse þus esely
msItem.explicit:
So I prey yow what is cometh or was loke who is him þat wele done has
Nowe lorde Ihesu I crye þee nowe mercy To do penaunce or þat I hens dye
msItem.note:
Eight lines. Edited in Cambridge Middle English Lyrics, ed. Person (1962), 25.
IMEV 317.

msItem.title: Augustinian prose text
msItem.rubric: Augustinius dicit
msItem.incipit: Quod prima die quando anima exit de corpore, exit ad Jherusalem
msItem.note: In nine parts, unedited.

msItem.title: Chronicle of England in Latin with dates
msItem.rubric: Here nexst foloweþe a truwe cronicle of Englisshe vercefyed in Latyne. withe þe diuers dates. abstracte by Cronicles of Englande
msItem.incipit: HIc nato xpo [Cristoforo] mundi numerus datur isto - v M1 iiijxx xix
msItem.explicit: Finis adest mundi queratur vila secundi - M1 cccc &c
msItem.note: Thirty seven leonine verses, each with a date. Unedited.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Verses on the Kings of England (to Henry VI)
msItem.rubric:
Nowe here folowen þe names of þe Kinges of England frome þe conquest of Duc William of Normandye
Duc and Kynge William conquerour
msItem.incipit:
Tis mighty William Duke of Normandie
As bookis olde maken mencyoun
msItem.explicit:
Of vertuous lyff chosyn him for his knight
Longe to reioysshe and regne here in his right
msItem.note:
Fifteen seven-line stanzas. Edited in Historical Poems of the XIV and XV Centuries, ed. Robbins (1959), 3-6.
IMEV 3632.

msItem.title: Prose text of Thomas of Canterbury
msItem.rubric: Here now foloweþe nexst a scripture in latyn prosed in feyre cadence whiche saint Thomas of Caunturbury martyre and martyr lefft wryten in auricalco he beinge Archebusshoppe
msItem.incipit: CUm Ego Thomas Cantuaria Archiepiscopus exul ab Anglia
msItem.note: Prose. Unedited.

msItem.title: Merlin's Prophecy
msItem.rubric: Prophecia Merlini doctoris perfecti
msItem.incipit:
Whane lordes wol leese þeire olde lawes
And preestis beon varyinge in þeire sawes
msItem.explicit:
þat is islande of Albyoun
Nexst to his confusyoun
msItem.note:
Imperfect: eight lines only. Edited in Walter William Skeat, Merlin’s Prophecy, Athenaeum 108 (1896): 874.
IMEV 3943.

msItem.title: Prophecy
msItem.rubric: Alia prophesia
msItem.incipit: Cesaris imperium per tempora longa patebit
msItem.explicit: Ealli cum bruto cuntos gos supabunt
msItem.note: Nine lines. Unedited.

msItem.title: Doctrine of Saint Augustine
msItem.rubric: Nowe filoweþe here nexst þe doctryne of þat solempne and holy doctour saint Austyne . articled in prose for pe savacoun boþe of bodye and soule to alle cristen nacoun
msItem.incipit: Knowe þy self seyþe and techeþe vs saint Austyne þat gloryous doctour
msItem.explicit: Were a man made of eorþe of claye made of claye and eorþe þou arte and to eorþe shalt owe tomne agoyne
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit. Nowe eondeþe here þe prose of þe holy doctour saint Austyne
msItem.note:
Prose. Unedited.
IMEP IX.

msItem.title: Cur mundus militat
msItem.rubric: and nexst filowynge begynneþe a ensaumple of þe same putte in vercyfical metre of Ryme
msItem.incipit:
WHy is þis worlde beloved þat fals is and veyne
Such alle haue welthes been in vncerteyne
msItem.explicit:
But for alsmuche as every man most dyd
Here is no wye but sorowe leve sik
msItem.note:
Twenty couplets. The verse Car mundus militat sub vana gloria is written in the margin of folio 83r. Edited in A Selection of Religious Lyrics, ed. Douglas Gray (Oxford: Clarendon, 1975), 89.
IMEV 4160.

msItem.title: Words of Jerome
msItem.rubric: Here nowe nexst folowe þe wordes of Jerome þe prophete
msItem.incipit: Quando senes erunt sine sensu
msItem.explicit: Bestia eirentalis et leo ocadentalis rumersum mundiun submyabrunt
msItem.note: Prose. Unedited.

msItem.title: Prophecy
msItem.incipit: Velit aut nolit totus mundus
msItem.explicit: Rustica gens optima flens set pessima gaudens
msItem.note: Contains the name Sibille la sage in between prophecies. Unedited.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Summum Sapientie
msItem.rubric: Here folowen nowe þe seyinges of wysemen of Prophetes of Poetes of Philosophres of hooly men of gret and Autorysed Clerkes of þe olde testament and of þe nuwe
msItem.incipit:
þE tyme approcheþe of necessite
To reherce þe material sentence
msItem.explicit:
þane after þis worlde transmygracoun
In heven have youre habitacyoun
msItem.note:
One hundred and sixteen seven-line stanzas. Names of the philosophers written in the margins as glosses to the text. Edited in Förster, Kleine Mitteilungen zur mittelenglische Lehrdichtung, VI., 293-309.
IMEV 3487.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Stans Puer ad Mensam
msItem.rubric: And here nowe foloweþe nest a doctryne of Curteysye cleped in Latyne . Stans puer ad mensam domini . translated in to Englisshe in balade wyse by Lidegate þe religious of Bury
msItem.incipit:
My dere chylde first þy self enable
With al þyne herte to vertuous desciplyne
msItem.explicit:
If ought be amisse in worde sillabul or dyte
Put al defaute vpon Iohn Lydegate
msItem.note:
Fourteen seven-line stanzas. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961), 739-44.
IMEV 2233.

msItem.title: The Three Kings of Cologne
msItem.rubric: Here nowe foloweþe an holy solempne and a trewe cronicle of oure cristen feythe . translated oute of Latyne in to Englisshe by þe grettest doctours of oure nacioun . licenced by þe chirche þat entreteþe of þe birthe of Cryste affter holy scripture
msItem.incipit: The vertue and þe might of almighty god of heven þe fader
msItem.explicit: and þere so abydene in to þis daye &
msItem.finalRubric: Thus nowe here endeþe þis wondrefulle and honourable translacioun of þeos thre holy kynges of Ynde þat first worshiped Cryste in Bedleme affter his birthe
msItem.note:
Prose, in thirty-eight chapters, with chapter numbers written in outer margin. Edited in The Three Kings of Cologne: An Early English Translation of the Historia Trium Regum, ed. C. Horstmann, Early English Text Society o.s. 85 (Oxford, 1886).
IMEP IX.

msItem.title: Prester John continuation
msItem.rubric: And foloweþe nest þe cronycle of þat mighty Patryarche cleped Prestre Johan nowe of Ynde
msItem.incipit: PRestre Johan þat is lord of Ynde and all þe kynges þat beon under his dominacoun
msItem.explicit: and also þe sarasines þat been of Machametis lawe and oþer turkes have þeos
msItem.note:
Prose. On folio 129v the account of the place where John is baptized is signalled with Capitulum xxxix as if this text is a continuation of the previous. The bottom two-thirds of the last folio (130) has been cropped with the gutter still present, but the empty space beneath the final line of this text suggests that none of the main text has been lost, but it is likely that it was once followed by a final rubric (following the pattern of Shirley's other texts). There is evidence in the gutter of further writing lower on the page, closer to the margin than the Prester John continuation. Unedited.
IMEP IX.

msItem.title: The morow off screfte
msItem.incipit: I am a knowe to god and to our Lady seynt mary and to all þe blyssyd company of heven
msItem.explicit: as mych þat I haue noȝt loued my god bow all oþer thyngys and haf more
msItem.note:
Incomplete confessional text in prose, in a different hand and darker ink to John Shirley, also of the fifteenth century. This is the sole witness (see Joliffe, A Checklist of Middle English Prose Writings of Spiritual Guidance, 165-6), although this style of confessional text is commonplace. The bottom two-thirds of the page has been cropped with the loss of text, visible from the remnants of ascenders. Unedited.
IMEP IX.

msItem.title: Recipe for the stone
msItem.rubric: Pulvis pro petra comendedus ter in die si infirmus voluerit est iste
msItem.incipit: Take persley sed the sed of saxifrage
msItem.explicit: & habebit cito enixiline remedaturum est
msItem.note:
Prose. Begins in English and changes to Latin half way through. In a different hand, also of the fifteenth century. Unedited.
IMEP IX.

msItem.title: Recipe for all manner of sickness
msItem.rubric: A gode powder ffor all maner of sekenes yn a manys stomak and for the dropese and for the gaundys
msItem.incipit: Take the sede of smallache and layoff
msItem.explicit: ffore days next thenne
msItem.note:
Prose. In a different hand, also of the late fifteenth century. Unedited.
IMEP IX.

msItem.title: Recipe for a cough
msItem.rubric: For hem þat haþ a perelless coche
msItem.incipit: Take sauge rewe and comyn and powder of peper
msItem.explicit: wse ther of a sponfull at nytte and another at moro
msItem.note:
Prose. In the same hand as the previous. Unedited.
IMEP IX.

msItem.title: Treatise on Egyptian Days
msItem.incipit: Therre ben iiy fryydays in the yere that who that euer fast
msItem.explicit: the fyrst munday of feverrere and þe last munday of may and the last munday of december
msItem.note:
Prose. In the same hand as item 68. Edited in English Language Notes, 13 (1975), 90.
IMEP IX.

msItem.author: Ps.-Aristotle
msItem.title: Secreta secretorum
msItem.note: (English verse tr. by John Lydgate and Benedict Burgh )
msItem.incipit:
God all myghty saue and conserue owre kynge
In all vertye to hys Encrese off glorye
msItem.explicit:
Wit drede and loue to haue memorye
Of hys enmyes conquest and victory
msItem.note:
Imperfect, first five lines only of a prayer to Henry VI. In a different hand and ink to John Shirley, also of the fifteenth century. Possibly the hand of the annotation John tatt (see Provenance below). Edited in Rossell Hope Robbins, Historical Poems of the XIV and XV Centuries (New York, 1959), 196.
IMEV 935.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Deus in Nomine Tuo saluum me Fac
msItem.incipit: ffor why good lord thou haste me saved & kepte
msItem.explicit: That I might amend whyles I haue tyme & space
msItem.note: Imperfect, one stanza of eight. The rest of this poem appears on folios 69v-70v, lacking this stanza. This extract is copied in a different hand and ink to John Shirley, also of the fifteenth century, possibly the hand of the recipes (items 69 and 70).

msItem.title: Illegible verse
msItem.incipit: thou be dred the nowne consyens
msItem.explicit: sylf ye thou mayst not parde
msItem.note: Unidentified verse in seven lines, heavily damaged and corrected. Fifteenth-century hand.

msItem.title: Recipe for sciatica
msItem.incipit:
the tyme for to delate
ffore the scyetica pascio
msItem.explicit: and wrappit wit a towel & go to bed fore the hete thereof wil senk out the ache
msItem.note: Prose, heavily damaged and illegible in parts. In the same hand as the recipes (items 69 and 70).

supportDesc.extent:
ii + 133 + i fols. 275 197
200 90–130
200 140
Two watermarks throughout, both similar with bull's head design surmounted by a diagonal cross, similar to Piccard VII 661-4 (1449-51) and Briquet 15101-3 (1441-62). Possibly from the same stock. R.J. Lyall notes that two watermarks are used in this first codicological unit, of a variety that was rare before 1445 and unknown before 1440 (R.J. Lyall, Materials: The Paper Revolution, Book Production and Publishing in Britain 1395-1475, eds J. Griffiths and D. Pearsall (21)).
supportDesc.collation:
12 (fols. i-ii, parchment flyleaves, unfoliated), 2-312 (fols. 1-24), 410 (fols. 25-34), 5-612 (fols. 35-58), 712-1 (fols. 59-69, first folio excised with loss of text), 810 (fols. 70-79), 9-1212 (fols. 80-126), 13 (collation uncertain).
Some disruption to the original collation of this first part has occurred. The present system of quire numbers runs from i-xi (excluding the final quire which is not numbered), but a previous system can be seen which is now cancelled which ran from xiii-xxiii (also excluding the final quire). Margaret Connolly suggests both systems are in Shirley's hand (John Shirley (1998), 150), and that Shirley is responsible for assembling the twelve gatherings into one codicological unit (151). Catchwords are present at the end of most quires, with the exception of those missing the last leaf. The tenth quire (fols. 92-103) ends with a list of five variations of catchword, all in the same hand, with four cancelled. None match the text at the beginning of the eleventh quire.
supportDesc.condition: The flyleaves display more damage than the paper text block, with wormholes and wear to the outer margins. The outer leaves (folios 1r and 133v) are particularly discoloured, suggesting this first part existed for a time without a binding. The condition of the paper leaves is good, with only minor wear and discolouration to the outer margins. Gutters fragile. Occasional tears.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 column, between 29-30 lines, frame ruled only.

handDesc.handNote: Predominantly in one hand, John Shirley (parchment flyleaves and folios 1-130r), in a consistent secretary script of the mid fifteenth century.
A second fifteenth-century hand on folio 130v, also in a secretary script but displaying some anglicana influences.
A third hand on folio 131v, also of the fifteenth century, in a more formal anglicana script.
A fourth hand on folios 131v-132r in a scruffy secretary script of the late fifteenth-early sixteenth century.
A fifth hand on folios 132v-133r and 134r in a neat secretary script of the mid fifteenth century.

decoDesc.decoNote: Every text opens with a three or four line lombardic capital, in the same ink as the main text but often with added flourishes or decorations. Every initial is accompanied by a decorated cross symbol in the left margin - a design Shirley also uses in another manuscript, Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.3.20, there referred to as a lozenge feature. In the Secreta secretorum and The Three Kings of Cologne, the same flourished lombards and cross symbols are used to mark points of textual division within the text.
The beginning of some texts are marked with the planetary symbol for Mercury, a simplified caduceus ☿, in the margin. It is unclear if these are Shirley's additions or by a later hand.

When the rubric to a text falls at the top of a page, the ascenders of the top line are flourished. The first letter of the page and some top-line ascenders in the main text are occasionally, but inconsistently, flourished.

physDesc.additions:
Shirley writes a note to the reader in between two texts on folio 59v: whane yee þis boke haue overredde and seyne
To Johan shirley restore yee it ageine. Shirley also annotates his own name in the margin: nota per Shirley, for instance folios 1v, 2v, 3r.
Every text is accompanied by a running title at the top of the page in Shirley's hand.
The hand of William Brown(e) can be identified throughout in marginal annotations, often unrelated to the text. On folios ii v and 20v the phrase Prayer is an worke of the is inverted in the lower margin. Brown(e) leaves comparable marginal annotations in MS Ashmole 40.
Annotations appear throughout in several hands. A later hand (sixteenth century?) annotates the Secreta secretorum and the Cur mundus militat in a faded light brown ink. Another late hand of a similar period highlights a leson in Gower's Balade moral of gode counseyle on folio 17v. A seventeenth-century hand correctly identifies Chaucer's Gentillesse on folio 25r and notes that it is Printed toward the end of Chaucers works. The same hand leaves the same note on folio 37r at the beginning of Chaucer's Balade of Fortune. A fifteenth-century hand annotates Wysdome the gyfte of ' on folio 83r, now trimmed.
Erased writing on folio 14r-v, illegible under UV.
Pen trials on folios 63v-64r, 65v in a sixteenth-century hand (possibly that of John Snowe, see Provenance below). On folio 64r, possibly in the same hand, is a marginal drawing of an irregular shape with a grid pattern and containing several faces, possibly emulating a coat of arms.
A later hand has numbered the texts in red pencil, imperfectly.

history.provenance: The first composite part and the parchment flyleaves containing the table of contents are predominantly in the hand of John Shirley, 1366?–1456. The first part was written between Shirley's death in 1456 and the death of Humfrey duke of Gloucester in Feb. 1447 (which is described on folio 57). The dating of the parchment flyleaves is unclear. Other hands appear only on folio 130v and on the paper leaves at the end of the first part.

It is possible these parts were in the possession of the Walsingham family, or one of their supporters, in the sixteenth century. A sixteenth-century hand writes Fra. Walsingham memorandum remayning and memorand on folio 131r, likely Sir Francis Walsingham (c.1532-1590), principal secretary to Queen Elizabeth I. The same hand leaves numerous annotations on folio 133v: Babington (likely a reference to the Babington Plot, a plan in 1586 to assassinate Queen Elizabeth I which was discovered by Walsingham), Actuall and criminall, Accused and condempned, Nowe sure a goodly peece of worke
desireth and thirsteth
desireth
desireth and thirs, memorandum his.
At some point, the manuscript was in the possession of John Stow (1525?–1605), whose hand appears on folios i r and 17v (identified by Connolly, John Shirley (1998), 150).

It is unclear when the flyleaves and first part were joined, however it was before 1614 as both contain the ownership marks and annotations of the poet William Brown(e), author of Britannia’s Pastorals (1613–16) and Oxford alumnus (matriculated 30 April 1624). His name appears on folio 1r: Liber W. Browne; and folio 133v: W. Browne Inter. Templi, 1614, and his annotations on the parchment flyleaves and throughout the text block. Browne is known to have owned other manuscripts with Lydgate and Lydgatean material, such as BodL MS Ashmole 45, BL Additional MS 34360, BL Lansdowne MS 699, Durham V ii 15, and Durham V ii 16.

The parchment flyleaves and first part likely circulated as a separate bound codex before being compiled with the second part. The final folio 134 is significantly worn and displays wormholes typical of wooden boards. A note on this folio in an early hand, possibly sixteenth-century, records that there are 136 1/4 folio, which would include the parchment flyleaves and first part. Evidence of prior sewing can also be seen in the gutters of both the flyleaves and first part, and the remnants of the old threads can still be seen which run through both elements.

Several names are recorded in the margins throughout which cannot be identified with certainty. A late sixteenth-century hand records the name John Snowe three times (folios 56v, 66v (heavily cancelled), and 69v), and the name Godmershame on folio 90v, presumably the village of Godmersham in Kent. Brother inverted in the lower margin of folio 78v in a sixteenth-seventeenth century hand. The same Godmersham inscription appears on folio 133v, now cancelled. Several names are also recorded on folio 134v: Tomas Situn (all but the first T now erased and only visible under UV), Iste liber constat bono domino. A now trimmed note in the corner of folio 131r reads John tatt in an early hand (perhaps fifteenth century).

A bookseller's cypher consisting of the letter v/b above the letter m divided by a line, is written in the outer margin of folio ii r. Connolly suggests a date of the seventeenth century (John Shirley (1998), 166 n.13).
The manuscript was later owned by Elias Ashmole (1617–1692), who acquired other manuscripts from Brown(e).

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Life of Our Lady
msItem.rubric: Folio 135r is a title page containing the rubric Here beginneth a booke of our blessed Lady Maiden Moder & Wife of our Lord Ihesu Compiled by Daune Johan Lidgate Monke of Bery at the exhortation of our most excellent Prince King Henry ye fifte. In honour glory and Worship of her Natiuite and of her most holy liuinge and conuersation from her birthe to her Purification, written centrally in the style of an early printed book's title page. A similar rubric appears in another Shirley manuscript, TCC R.3.22 (folio 1r). The text begins on folio 136r.
Of the Natiuitie of our Lady and how she was offred up on þe Temple Cap i
msItem.incipit:
O fflowre of vertue ful long kepyt in close
ffull many a yeare with wholesom leaues swete
msItem.explicit:
Petra dat huic nitidum fugit hostem flumine visum
Rostro non ledit geminos pullos bene nutrit
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the booke of the Life of our Lady made by Dan John Lidegate monke of Bury at thinstaunce of the most Christen kyng Henry the fift
msItem.note:
Imperfect, lacking the prologue and Books V and VI. Folio 180v begins with the title Comparatio Turturio as if commencing another item; this is in fact lines 1-301 of chapter 26 of Book VI.
IMEV 2574.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Envoy to Life of Our Lady
msItem.incipit:
Go litel booke and submit the
Unto al them that shal rede the
msItem.explicit:
Blesse us marie the most holly vergyne
That we regne in heven wit the ordres myne
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Life off our Lady
msItem.note: Envoy, in the same hand.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fall of Princes
msItem.incipit:
In his studye allone as Bochas stode
His penne in hond of sodeyn aventure
msItem.explicit:
Now was she mannysshe now was she ffemynyne
Now coulde she reyne now could she falsly shyne
msItem.note:
Extract - one leaf only, containing lines 1-63 of Book VI.
IMEV 1168.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Song of Vertu
msItem.incipit:
Off Rethoriciens men lerne ffresshe language
Off holy saintes procedith parfitnes
msItem.explicit:
Cleyme of his mercy to haue possession
hym to dwell aboue the sterris Clere
msItem.note:
Imperfect, lacking stanzas 1-5 due to the loss of a leaf. Edited in The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems, ed. MacCracken (1934, repr. 1961),835-8.
IMEV 401.

extent.watermark: Two watermarks throughout, similar to Piccard 31681 (Sankt Germain, 1556); and Piccard 31768 (Narwa, 1541).

supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in same hand as Part 1, inconsistently, in brown ink.
supportDesc.collation: 110 (fols. 135-144), 218+1 (fols. 145-184, with the addition of the nineteenth folio)
supportDesc.condition: Paper condition good, gutters delicate and wear to final folio.

layoutDesc.layout: Folios 136r-143v: 1 column, between 25-40 lines, no ruling.
Folios 144r-184v: 1 column, between 32-39 lines, frame ruled only.

handDesc.handNote: The hand changes noticeably at folio 143v. The first hand is an untidy cursive secretary of the sixteenth century. This hand copies the first sixteen pages without ruling and in varying levels of size and legibility, ending at the foot of folio 143v mid-stanza. The second hand continues the stanza at the top of folio 144r, in a neater secretary script with anglicana influences. This hand is more consistent in size and writes within frame ruling.

decoDesc.decoNote: The first letter of stanzas in the first scribe's pages of Life of Our Lady are minimally flourished, without the use of colour.
Section titles are provided by the second scribe of Life of Our Lady interlinear in a textualis script in the same ink.

The division between books 2 and 3 of Life of Our Lady is marked with a decorative Explicit and Incipit in a textualis script with flourished ascenders and descenders, in the same ink. The second explicit of this text on folio 182r is similarly decorated.
The beginning of the extract of Fall of Princes opens with a one-line Lombardic capitol, unfilled, which extends above the stanza.

physDesc.additions:
A later hand annotates the chapter numbers of Lydgate's Life of Our Lady in the margin.
Pen trials on folios 159r and 184r-v.

history.provenance: This second part likely circulated independently before it was bound with the first part, from evidence of prior sewing in the gutter.
There are no names or marginal annotations in this part to suggest provenance. It is likely the two parts were bound together by Ashmole, as was his practice.

revisionDesc.change: James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
